conclusion: Identify the interval in which the block is sliding on the plate
From the instant it is 'gently placed' (t = 0) the block is at rest while the plate is still moving to the right.
Consequently the two surfaces are in relative motion and the only horizontal force acting on the block is the kinetic-friction force exerted by the plate.

On the v–t graph this part of the motion is the straight-line section that starts at the origin (v = 0 when t = 0) and ends at the moment the block and the plate obtain the same speed (the peak of the graph).
The graph in Fig. B shows that at t = 0, v = 0.
The graph in Fig. B shows that at t = 2.0 s, v = 4.0 m/s.

premise: The velocity therefore increases uniformly from 0 to 4.0 m/s in 2.0 s.
conclusion: Determine the acceleration of the block while it is sliding

premise: For a straight-line portion of a v–t graph the slope equals the (constant) acceleration.
Relate that acceleration to the coefficient of kinetic friction
conclusion: During the sliding interval the horizontal force on the block is the kinetic-friction force Fₖ = μ₁ m g

premise: Hence the horizontal equation of motion of the block is Fₖ = m a₁ ⇒ μ₁ m g = m a₁ ⇒ μ₁ = a₁ / g
conclusion: Using g = 10 m/s² and the acceleration found in Step 2, μ₁ = 2.0 m/s² / 10 m/s² = 0.20
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the plate is μ₁ = 0.20
